keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up' at the airport.
Although not armed at the time of arrest, Cagle was found with an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside the airport.

Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm during a felony, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.
The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, which handles over 108 million passengers annually and is the busiest in the world.
Cagle was already at the airport before authorities were informed, having arrived shortly before 9:30 a.m. and showing interest in the TSA check-in area, which is heavily crowded.
His family alerted Cartersville police via social media livestream, prompting coordination between local and federal law enforcement.
Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum described the event as a 'tragedy averted,' emphasizing the role of public vigilance and early reporting.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised law enforcement for preventing a potential act of violence.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over 20 years ago and is currently without a known attorney.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation due to the federal nature of the charges, including interstate threats and firearms-related offenses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the world’s busiest airport, after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Although not armed at the time of arrest, police discovered an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside. Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm. He had already arrived at the airport before authorities were notified, showing interest in the crowded TSA check-in area. The incident was described by Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum as a 'tragedy averted' due to early intervention by family members and law enforcement coordination. FBI and federal authorities are involved, and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised the successful outcome. Cagle, who has a prior marijuana conviction over two decades ago, remains without legal representation.
